Any other fans here?
 
 My favourite band.
 
 I still get upset if I dwell on it too long. Hard to believe it's been 10 years.
 
 It's sad I know, but the band, and the "grunge" scene in general, had a huge part in making me the person I am today. Every contribution a positive one IMHO, it greatly broadened the horizons of a kid from small town nowhere.
 
 Unfortunately, the backlash also lead us to 10 years of sheety music.
 
 Waxy
Big fan here also. Your not kidding about the last ten years. There has been afew worth mentioning but nothing new in quit some time.

I am a fan!

 Just curious what other people think about that theory.

I hate that bitch, but I don't think she was directly involved.

I know we've posted on this before - hate.
 
 Maybe not hate, but my feelings for her go far beyond a "strong dislike". I obviously will never know all the details - but my opinion is that she was a manipulative leech. She may not have put a gun to his head, and maybe there was nothing anyone could do, but at the very least, I think she enabled him. 
 
 I also despise the way she dealt with the remaining band members, and even more so, what she's done with her life in front of her daughter's eyes.

Nirvana was great.
 
 But give the last ten years some credit. Rock did not diue with Curt. I can think of lots of other great bands from that time and since. 
 
 The Offspring
 Pearl Jam
 Live
 White Stripes
 Jet
 Everclear
 CAKE
 Audioslave
 Concrete Blonde
 The Strokes
 The Vines
 Green Day
 The Hives
 The Music
 Rage Against the Machine
 Fishbone
 The Headstones
 The Donnas
 Sound Garden
 Red Hot Chili Peppers
 
 and how about the Foo Fighters?
 
 And then there is plenty of other stuff that I am forgetting... or that is older...
 
 I just get sad when people get stuck in the "all new music is.....". It's horribly insulting to up and coming and new musicians that are busting butt and are just as passionate about music. (I know a lot of musicians.)
 
 Granted - one may have to look a little harder for the good stuff with companies light Clear Channel and Disney running all the radio stations.

 I don't know that I agree with that either. Many of the bands on my list are not "grunge". Concrete Blonde is out of punk, Cake and the Chili Peppers fell from funk, Jet is a throw back to the Beatles.
 
 Plus, most of the 4th generation watered down grunge you hear today (Nickelback, Creed) BLOWS! Maybe really good grunge died with Curt, though....sigh

 Concrete Blond?
 
 The Chili Peppers especially, but Cake and other funk bands as well, owe a HUGE debt of gratitude to the "grunge" scene for allowing them to access the mainstream and major label contracts. The Peppers are a great band, but without Nirvana, would they have had the mainstream success they've had? I'd say no. They'd have been a great punk/funk bad like so many before and so many after, playing to small crowds of devoted fans.
 
 I really don't like Creed, Nickleback (from a town about 1/2hr from where I live), and other "alternative" bands, but I can't stand most of the bands on hard rock radio today. POD, Godsmack, Limp Bizkit, Puddle of Mud, etc... they all suck IMHO. 
 
 I guess I've become an old fuddy dud.

 Dude! Where do you learn your rock history!???
 
 Chili Peppers aren't punk and were actually six albums in when Nirvana released Nevermind. And to be straight - Chili Peppers are a signifigantly better band. Especially the rythem section. Nobody can rock a bass like Flea.
 
 As far as grunge opening the door for punk or funk at all - that is straight up laughable. Both funk and punk boomed in the 70s. The Clash, The Sex Pistols and The Ramones were hot when Cobain was still a brat. If anything punk oponed doors for future offshoots of difference and anger - like grunge. 
 
 Don't get me wrong - I love Nirvana, but you give them entirely too much credit. They opened the door to grunge. That's it. And they were far from the first band in history to do something "new".
 
 Concrete Blonde is AWESOME. Nobody sings like Johnette - nobody!

Dude! Where do you learn your rock history!???
 
 Chili Peppers aren't punk and were actually six albums in when Nirvana released Nevermind. And to be straight - Chili Peppers are a signifigantly better band. Especially the rythem section. Nobody can rock a bass like Flea.
 
 As far as grunge opening the door for punk or funk at all - that is straight up laughable. Both funk and punk boomed in the 70s. The Clash, The Sex Pistols and The Ramones were hot when Cobain was still a brat. If anything punk oponed doors for future offshoots of difference and anger - like grunge. 
 
 Don't get me wrong - I love Nirvana, but you give them entirely too much credit. They opened the door to grunge. That's it. And they were far from the first band in history to do something "new".
 
 Concrete Blonde is AWESOME. Nobody sings like Johnette - nobody!

 
 I don't need a history lesson. Thanks though, glad you got a laugh.
 
 What were the sales of the Pepper's (whom I referred to as funk) first 6 albums compared to BSSM released during the height of the "grunge" scene? As for being a better band, no question in my mind who's better (except for Flea, he's definately a better bass player than Novoselic), we'll have to agree to disagree on that one.
 
 Where did I mention punk owing it's existance to Nirvana? Read the post with your mind jitobear, not your heart. I mentioned punk gaining a MAINSTREAM acceptance. Sales of "punk" albums skyrocketed during the grunge years due to most Seattle bands listing them as primary influences. Grunge didn't beget punk, I never even hinted at that, obviously the opposite is true, but it did do wonders to bring it to the forefront.
 
 How many young kids then, and even now, do you think would have Meat Puppets, Pixies or even Ramones albums had it not been for that boost? No doubt the smart ones would find it, but the numbers would be a lot less.
 
 Also, I don't place the success/influence squarely on Nirvana, lots of other Seattle bands, and non-Seattle bands, were influential at that time.
 
 I like Concrete Blond, and she does have a great voice, I was just surprised at their inclusion in this particular discussion that's all.
 
 Waxy

I don't need a history lesson. Thanks though, glad you got a laugh.
 
 What were the sales of the Pepper's (whom I referred to as funk) first 6 albums compared to BSSM released during the height of the "grunge" scene?

 
 Album six was BSSM and it came out the same year as Nevermind. However as the Peppers already had gained commercial success with Mother's Milk in '89 I absolutely do not give one ounce of credit to Nirvana for the Chili Pepper's success.
 
 
As for being a better band, no question in my mind who's better (except for Flea, he's definately a better bass player than Novoselic), we'll have to agree to disagree on that one.

 
 Yep. Even though I am right. ;)
 
 
Where did I mention punk owing it's existance to Nirvana? Read the post with your mind jitobear, not your heart. I mentioned punk gaining a MAINSTREAM acceptance. Sales of "punk" albums skyrocketed during the grunge years due to most Seattle bands listing them as primary influences. Grunge didn't beget punk, I never even hinted at that, obviously the opposite is true, but it did do wonders to bring it to the forefront.
 
 How many young kids then, and even now, do you think would have Meat Puppets, Pixies or even Ramones albums had it not been for that boost? No doubt the smart ones would find it, but the numbers would be a lot less.

 
 We have got to be talking different generations here. Mine did not need the grunge scene to embrace punk - we already had! You may be correct regarding younger fans, though.
 
 
Also, I don't place the success/influence squarely on Nirvana, lots of other Seattle bands, and non-Seattle bands, were influential at that time.

 
 They were easily the most influencial sound of the 90s. And they made a hugely signifigant shift in the sound of rock. But they are not to have credit for more than what they did. 
 
 
I like Concrete Blond, and she does have a great voice, I was just surprised at their inclusion in this particular discussion that's all.

 
 Oh. The question mark had me thinking you did not know who they were. They are considered part of the 80s punk scene - and I adore them. Which is why I mentioned them. A chic - that voice - AND a bass. That wins for me! (I play bass.)

Maynard has some of the best lungs in rock.

 
 "Thinking mans metal" as Sinjin quoted..
 I love Tool, we have been to so many shows, I will never miss a TOOL concert. Maynard is amazing live! As you can see by my avatar I am a huge fan.

Album six was BSSM and it came out the same year as Nevermind. However as the Peppers already had gained commercial success with Mother's Milk in '89 I absolutely do not give one ounce of credit to Nirvana for the Chili Pepper's success.

 
 Limited commerical success.
 
 Be that as it may, IMHO, it's undeniable. The entire music scene shifted in the direction of music more in line with what the Peppers do. 
 
 I do think that the street wasn't entirely one way though. 
 
 
Yep. Even though I am right. ;)

 
 Kurt over Anthony, easy win. Kurt over Anthony/Frusiante, a lot closer, but Kurt still wins.
 
 Dave Grohl KILLS Chad Smith, that one is "laughable". :p 
 
 I put most of the weight on live shows, (even though I was never lucky enough to see Nirvana live, and haven't seen RHCP live YET) and from the footage I've seen, there's no comparison.
 
 
We have got to be talking different generations here. Mine did not need the grunge scene to embrace punk - we already had! You may be correct regarding younger fans, though.

 
 I think we agree here, we're just splitting hairs. Scenes can be strong, and not be commercially successful. I don't doubt you embraced punk, but did every other MAINSTREAM blue collar man/woman out there also buy the records like they did in the early '90s?
 
 You were lucky enough to be around during punk prime time, I was not. However, and this is just a guess on my part, I'd bet that several, if not most, punk bands actually sold as many, or more, albums during the early '90s than they did in the prime of the punk era.
 
 
Oh. The question mark had me thinking you did not know who they were. They are considered part of the 80s punk scene - and I adore them. Which is why I mentioned them. A chic - that voice - AND a bass. That wins for me! (I play bass.)

 
 The only album I have is the one with "Joey" on it, I can't even remember the name of it. I haven't listened to it in a while, I better dig it out.

 They didnt have a significant release until 86 or 87 and by that time, the punk scene had changed a lot.
 I think Joey was in 90.. and bloodletting was before that...
 I might be a little off on the dates but I can sure remember the punk scene :) and Concrete was much later

Dave Grohl KILLS Chad Smith, that one is "laughable". :p

I put most of the weight on live shows, (even though I was never lucky enough to see Nirvana live, and haven't seen RHCP live YET) and from the footage I've seen, there's no comparison.

 
 Peppers are pretty dang kickin live - like you I never had the pleasure of seeing Nirvana live tho.
 
 I am a live music girl myself. I roughly see one show a week (usual local talent). All in all I am a brat and hate stadium shows. I much prefer seedy little venues and bars - where one can move freely and drink reasonably priced beer - out of the bottle. Next bigger show I am attending is The Offspring.
 
 
You were lucky enough to be around during punk prime time, I was not. However, and this is just a guess on my part, I'd bet that several, if not most, punk bands actually sold as many, or more, albums during the early '90s than they did in the prime of the punk era.

 
 I have no idea. It's possible.

 Bloodletting. Free and Mexican Moon are better. :)

 Look, the choices aren't Grunge **** (Nirvana) or Pop **** (Britney Spears). We don't live in a world of musical dichotomy. If I don't like something at one end of the spectrum, it doesn't mean I like music at the other end (which I don't). Get over yourselves, the world doesn't revolve around power chords, self pity, drug abuse, and screaming.

I believe the thread question was ...Any other fans here.... not anyone wanna dis the best grunge band theres ever been. why dont you go listen to some brintney spears, or Jessica simpson.

 
 This is facinating. It doesn't get any worse than this. So some once popular grunge band gets the treatment and suddenly it's detractors have a preference for a snot nosed pop princess. Has it occured to you or anyone that there is a bit more format diversification than a choice between an overated grunge band and tweeny pop? I never did get the popularity of Nirvana. They seemed mediocre at best. I prefer the following: Linkin Park, Boston, Phil Collins, Kansas, 3 Doors Down, Creed, John Mayer, Billy Joel, Credence Clearwater Revival, Puddle of Mudd, Bad Company, The Eagles, Gordon Lightfoot, Van Halen(with both David Lee Roth and Sammy Hagar), Journey, Ozzy Osbourne, ZZ Top, The Cars, David Bowie, Led Zeppelin, Incubus, Bon Jovi (not the recent stuff), Supertramp, The Doors, The Moody Blues, Yes, Breaking Benjamin, Foreigner, Kiss, Metallica, Rush, Ted Nugent, Toto, Pat Benatar, Pink Floyd, 5 For Fighting, Rush... Ok you get the point. The only pop princess I can really stomach (and there are a few of her songs I actually like) is Christina Aguilera. That may surprise some but as you can see from my list, my preferences vary and most certainly do NOT emphasize the silly blonde bimbos. 
 
 Next time, an essay on how some "liberal" artists misunderstand their audience (Linda Ronstadt pay attention).

My apologies, i was being more sarcastic then serious, i agree with most of your choices on music, i like nirvana because they express their frustration and anger into their songs. So I like them, i wont say you have to, its my choice....but out of many grunge bands i do think Nirvana hit the top 10. 
 
 Along with nirvana i like....tilt, the weakerthans, alanis morsette, Verve Pipe, Janes addiction, Weezer, Garbage, the beatles, Red hot chilli peppers, Modest mouse, i dunno...theres more i just cant think of them right now....
